direction.raw_text: A quiet upper-middle class neighborhood. The CAMERA is at the curb, looking down the street. There are no sidewalks. Trees arch overhead. CICADAS drone on the soundtrack. The OPENING TITLES briefly FADE IN and OUT, framed by the trees on either side of the street. Footsteps are heard approaching. As the picture TITLE FADES, out of the dark emerges a GIRL 17 years old, carrying schoolbooks. This is JILL. CAMERA PANS with her ninety degrees as she comes to the front of a house and stops. Lights are on in the bottom half of the house, and the curtains across the windows are open. A single light burns in the upper right side of the house, presumable in a bedroom, but the curtains in the room are drawn. A scene TITLE appears on the lower half of the screen: 8 pm Tuesday, March 23, 1971 The TITLE FADES, and Jill heads up the walk to the front door of the house. The light in the upper floor of the house is turned off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A middle-aged DOCTOR is standing at the foot of the stairs. His WIFE is descending the stairs, putting on her earrings. She is in an obvious hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doorbell rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crosses to the front door and opens it. The girl smiles at him uncomfortably from outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wife comes back into the front hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They cross to the front door and begin to exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doctor pokes his head back through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doctor pulls the door shut behind him. Jill turns toward the living room. Pause. She walks into the living room and sets her books down on a table with the telephone on it. O.S. we hear the car doors close, the engine start up, then the car backing out the driveway and heading down the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where's the girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I only called her ten minutes ago -- WIFE (passing into living room) I made our reservation for 8:15. We're going to be late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here she is now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Minakis?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mandrakis. It's okay. Everyone gets it wrong the first time. You're Jill? Come on in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (entering) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've written the number of the restaurant on the notepad by the phone. (to Doctor) Zip me up, will you please? (to Jill) If we aren't home in two hours, it means we've decided to go on to a movie and won't be back until after midnight. Is that all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (helping wife on with her coat) I've told my service to pick up any calls coming in to my office phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The children are asleep upstairs -- first door on your left at the top of the landing. They're both just getting over a cold -- so try not to wake them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have any questions?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to go now. We're late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make yourself at home. The refrigerator's loaded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling doctor through the door) Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We even have some low-fat yogurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Will you please come on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is dark. O.S. we hear the phone in the living room being lifted off its receiver, a dial tone, then a number is dialed. Pause, then ringing. CAMERA SLOWLY DOLLIES from the dining room, across the front hall and into the living room where we see Jill talking over the phone to a girlfriend, NANCY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill makes a face at the phone and hangs up. She tries to go back to her homework, but she cannot.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nancy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello, Jill? How's it going? (out of phone) I got it, Dad! (beat) Father! (into phone again) Jesus Christ! My father's in one of his moods again. Male menopause, you know. So how are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Are you over at Dr. Mandrakis'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I've been here for about an hour already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Isn't it a neat house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess... I haven't looked around very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Did you see his kids?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, they were asleep when I got here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) They're really cute. So what can I do for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't happen to talk to Billy today, did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yeah, I talked to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did he say anything about me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) I don't know what you did to him, or said to him, or what... but he's really pissed off at you! What did you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's what I didn't do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (sarcastic) Yeah, I can imagine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do me a favor, Nance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) What.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think you'll be talking with Billy some time tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Prabably. I'm going to the library in a few minutes. I just have to get out of this house! (beat) Hey! Why don't Billy and I come over there? He'll come along if I tell him to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That isn't what I had in mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You'll be safe with Billy. I'll be there. Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nancy, all you want to do is come over here and get drunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Who? Me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mimicking) Who? Me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You want to see Billy, don't you?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a lot of work to do. I don't want you coming over!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You know what your problem is, Jill, is you're so straight. I really mean that. You go to a private school, you wear a bra. No one can have a good time with you! (beat) You know, Billy asked me to go out with him this weekend, and I was really really tempted because I like Billy... a lot... as much as you do. But I told him I couldn't, that I didn't think it was right because you were my friend -- JILL You are my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yeah. I guess so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, just give Billy the number here, but don't tell him I told you to. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Okay. I've got to go now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Nancy. Bye. And thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yeah. Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill is working now, diligently. The phone rings. She picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a brief pause; then the line goes dead and a dial tone cuts in. Jill hangs up and goes back to work. Pause. The phone rings again. Jill picks it up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Billy?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: speaks on the other end of the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The line goes dead. Dial tone. Jill hangs up and goes right back to work.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Have you checked the children?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill sits at the table as before, doing her homework, smoking a cigarette. The phone rings. Jill picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The line goes dead. Dial tone. Jill hangs up and looks off into space, thinking. O.S. we hear a faint rattling noise from somewhere in the house. Jill hears it too. She stubs out her cigarette, gets up from the table and walks out of the living room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Have you checked the children?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Mandrakis?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill enters the hallway and pauses. Then she starts walking slowly down the hall to the kitchen door. Again the rattling noise O.S., only louder this time. Jill stops dead, listens, then continues forward even more cautiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Jill enters. She cannot find the lightswitch, so she stands in the darkness listening. Again the rattle, very close now. Jill turns her head sharply, then walks to the refrigerator and opens it. It is only the automatic icemaker creating the rattle. Jill takes a piece of cake from the refrigerator and leaves the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill is sitting at the table, polishing off the cake. Then, the phone rings. Jill stands up quickly and picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. "Billy" doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The line goes dead. Jill stands frozen beside the table with the phone in her hand as the dial tone gets louder and louder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Have you checked the children?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Billy! I don't think this is very funny!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Who is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill is standing at the wet bar in the corner, pouring herself a drink. She samples the alcohol, doesn't cough, and starts to pour a little more into the glass. The phone rings. Jill turns, then slowly walks to the table, kneels down and quietly picks up the phone and brings it to her ear. She waits and listens, a full three seconds. No sound comes to her. She quickly hangs up the phone before the silence can be broken by the voice she knows is waiting on the other end. Then, she shuffles through her books and papers on the table- top until she finds the notepad the doctor's wife has left for her with the name and phone number of the restaurant. Jill picks up the phone and dials. After several rings...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill waits for several seconds until the Maitre D' comes back on the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hangs up, thinks for a moment, then picks up the phone again and dials "O"...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill hangs up. After thinking for a moment, she tries a couple of ways of whistling as loud as she can, but frustrated and feeling foolish, she soon gives up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Golden Bull...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, I'd like to speak to Dr. Mandrakis. This is his babysitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hold on a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Dr. Mandrakis left the restaurant about forty minutes ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forty minutes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) Okay. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Operator...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Operator? Can you get me the police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Is this an emergency?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! (beat) No, not really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The number is 555-9431. Would you like me to connect you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Seventh Precinct, Sergeant Sacker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, I've been getting phone calls, every fifteen minutes or so. I think it's a man. He's trying to scare me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) An anonymous caller?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Has he threatened you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Has he been using obscene language?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. He just keeps calling me. Sometimes he doesn't say anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) There's really nothing we can do about it down here. Is the phone listed in your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm just the babysitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's probably just some weirdo. The city's full of them. Believe it or not, we get reports like this every night. It's nothing to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Have you tried whistling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) If you can find a good loud whistle somewhere in the house, blow it into the phone hard, next time he calls. Probably break his eardrum. He won't bother you after that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I... You're probably right. It's nothing to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Or you could just take your phone off the hook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, the people I'm babysitting for might try to reach me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Well, as I say, there's nothing we can really do to help you down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You bet. Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill is sitting in an armchair facing the TV set. The TV is on, but she is bored. She runs through several channels, then gets up and turns the TV off. She looks around and moves aimlessly back to the table, but O.S. a dog is barking and she is drawn to the window. A car passes outside, its lights reflecting off the window and Jill's face. Then the phone rings. Jill moves quickly from the window to the table and answers the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stunned, Jill hangs up the phone. She turns and goes slowly back to the window. She pulls the shutters closed in front of the window. Then she walks out of the living room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Why haven't you checked the children?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill goes to the front door, turns the bolt and draws the chain across the door. Then she starts to go upstairs. The phone rings. She stops halfway up the stairs. She turns and comes back down the stairs to answer the phone, but then thinks better of it. She sits on the bottom step and lets the phone ring and ring... Finally, it stops. Jill gets up and heads into the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill goes to the table, picks up the phone and dials...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill hangs up the phone and looks forlornly off into space.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Seventh Precinct, Sergeant Sacker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I called you before... about the man who keeps calling me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Oh, yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He called me again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Did you try whistling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he's out there somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Out where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the neighborhood. He's been watching me... through the windows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Did you see him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I know he's there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Is the house locked up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) And the windows?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Then you're safe. If he wanted to break in, he wouldn't be calling you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, can't you help me? I'm all alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Tell you what. If this guy calls you again -- JILL He will call again! I know he will!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Okay, calm down now. I can alert the phone company so that if he calls again we can try to trace the call. What's your number there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) And the address?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oakridge Drive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Oh, yeah, I know where that is. All right. If the guy calls again, try to keep him on the line for at least a minute so we can trace the call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he never stays on that long! Sometimes he hangs up after just a couple of seconds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's the only way we can help you. (beat) By the way, what's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jill Johnson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Jill, the important thing is to relax. You're safe where you are. We've got patrolmen cruising the area all night long. Just stay calm. Will you do that for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) In the meantime, we'll be watching your line. Okay, Jill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Call again if there's any problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill is sitting on the sofa, a drink in one hand, a cigarette in the other. She is waiting. She sets her glass down, stubs out the cigarette, leans back and sighs. She is very tense. Then the phone rings. She rises from the sofa and slowly crosses to the table. She sits down and picks up the phone. During this conversation it becomes apparent that the VOICE has a slight English accent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. No answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Jill is terrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Jill searches for some way of answering him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The line goes dead. Jill hangs up. She stands. She starts to shake. The phone rings and Jill snatches it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill hangs up. She stands frozen in shock. Several seconds go by. She doesn't move. Then the phone rings. She turns and tiptoes toward the front door. Halfway there, the phone stops ringing. She pauses for a second, then continues.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't be here much longer. The doctor and his wife are coming home soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you see me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning toward the window) I'm sorry I turned the lights down. It didn't work anyway. I can turn them back up if you like -- DUNCAN (O.S.) Don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't? (beat) You've really scared me. Is that what you wanted? (beat) Is that what you wanted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Your blood... all over me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't know me. You don't know who I am or where I live. I'll get Dr. Mandrakis to drive me home. Him or the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You've called the police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to talk to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave me alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Jill, this is Sergeant Sacker! Listen to me! (beat) We've traced the call. It's coming from within the house. A squad car's on its way over there now... just get out of that house!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill reaches the front door. Carefully, quietly, she turns the bolt. Then O.S. she hears a creak. She turns and looks up the staircase. At the top, a door is opening. Someone is coming out! A mumbling sound is heard on the sound track. Jill whirls around back to the door and yanks at it. It opens, but only an inch. The chain is still across it! She frantically works to get the chain free. After agonizing seconds, the chain falls clear and the door swings open. Standing there on the other side of the door, is a police Detective, JOHN CLIFFORD. (We have cut ahead in time some twenty or thirty minutes.) Behind him on the street, several patrol cars and an ambulance are pulled up at the curb, their domelights silently flashing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford sighs and steps into the front hall. The door is closed by the uniformed COP with whom Clifford has been speaking. The cop is a man in his thirties. His name is CHARLES GARBER. Garber and Clifford stand in the front hall and talk as POLICEMEN and AMBULANCE ATTENDANTS move around them. In the living room beyond can be seen several other POLICEMEN, Dr. Mandrakis and his wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Garber delivers his final line, we see ambulance attendants dressed in white, taking a sheet-covered stretcher out the front door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are the parents here yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yeah, they arrived about ten minutes ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christ! (beat) What a homecoming!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) They wanted to talk to someone. I asked them to wait until you got here. Come on in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were only a block away when the call went out. When we got here, the guy was still waiting upstairs in the children's bedroom. He was covered with blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not his own. The children had been dead for several hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'd been using an old phone in their bedroom that the parents had never had disconnected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We found a Merchant Seaman's card on him. He's English. Entered the country less than a week ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about the babysitter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's going to be all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An upper-class neighborhood. The CAMERA is facing down the street. A car approaches the intersection at the end of the block, turns and comes slowly up the street. Because it is not a new car or an expensive car, and because it is moving at a rate which suggests that its sole male occupant is looking for house numbers, we can assume that the DRIVER is a visitor to this neighborhood. The CAMERA PANS with the car ninety degrees as it turns into the semi-circular driveway of a mansion and rolls up to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: appears across the bottom of the screen:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the TITLE FADES, the driver shuts off the car engine and opens the door to get out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: :30 pm Thursday, April 20, 1978
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The doorbell rings. A HOUSEBOY comes into the front hall, goes to the door and opens it for the visitor. It is John Clifford, the detective from six years ago. He has aged noticeably over the years. His hair is grayer, his stance not so aggressive, but his eyes still smoulder with the accumulated frustration of having spent years in an uncertain, sometimes unsatisfying, and frequently unsafe occupation. No words are exchanged as the houseboy leads Clifford across the entrance hall and up an imposing flight of stairs. Still keen in his observation of things, Clifford quickly takes in this new atmosphere. The house is richly decorated but with an underlying theme of melancholy. There are no bright or cheerful furnishings, and the houseboy advances with guarded tread, his face steady and reverent. The houseboy stops before a door at the top of the staircase and raps lightly on it with his knuckles. Without waiting for an answer, he opens the door and steps aside for Clifford to enter. Clifford pauses briefly, then walks into what appears to be an upstairs study.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is sitting behind a desk which faces the door. Presumably he is the master of the house. Although his face is hidden in shadows, we can see from his hands that he is engaged in writing something down. Clifford quietly approaches the desk and takes a seat in front of it. Then, vaguely in keeping with the spirit of the house, he waits to be spoken to rather than interrupt the pervasive stillness. After a moment, the master of the house lays down his pen and leans back in his chair. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford lowers his eyes, doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The master of the house leans way forward over his desk, and his face comes out of the shadows and into the light. It is Dr. Mandrakis. He seems much older. His complexion is pallid. His eyes stare out from beneath his brow like a wounded animal hiding in a dark cave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other for a long moment of acknowledgment. Then Mandrakis stands up with a sigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford stands and they shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford turns to go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So you're in business for yourself now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Yes, sir, for the past three and a half years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's good. (beat) And you'd heard about Curt Duncan's escape?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think the police will... find him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know they haven't assigned anyone to it specifically. It's an old case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a tinge of bitterness) An old case. (beat) Can you find him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Maybe not tomorrow, maybe not this week, but I'll find him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He could be anywhere by now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so... because he's a foreigner. He'll come back to the city. After six years in confinement, it's the only place that's familiar to him. That's important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man murders two children in cold blood. A jury declares him insane. How could such a person not be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is sent to a state mental institution where the security is... less than perfect. And he escapes. It... it isn't fair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A thing like that should never be allowed to happen again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't agree with you more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead then. My accountant will contact you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. (beat) How is Mrs. Mandrakis?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She is... unable to have any more children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. Please give her my best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & ENTRANCE HALL As Clifford finds his own way down the stairs and out the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches Clifford leave from the back of the staircase. It is Mrs. Mandrakis. As with her husband, the change in her is remarkable. She is now a brooding, barren woman. O.S. the front door closes. Clifford is gone. Mrs. Mandrakis walks around the front of the stairs and begins slowly ascending them. The houseboy silently steps into the entrance hall from a side door and watches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A male PATIENT wearing green, institutional pajamas and slippers shuffles slowly up the hall. His movement is catatonic, unfocused. Canned Musak faintly underscores the scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Curt Duncan isn't going to run right out and kill more children. I'm not worried about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Standing in the doorway of an office, facing into the hall, watching the patient.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) We had him for six years... under continuous therapy, some of it rather forceful...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Moving past CAMERA. He is really out of it. It is a depressing, vaguely unnerving sight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) ...and drugs... tranquilizers depressants, lithium...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He turns and goes back into the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see now the MAN who's been talking -- the director of the State Hospital, DR. MONK. He is sitting comfortably behind his desk; his jacket off, his tie loosened, his feet up on the desk. He is very matter-of-fact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford sits down in front of the desk, picks up a folder and leafs through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monk shrugs, then yawns expansively. He needn't justify himself to the layman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Eventually, anyone will respond to the treatment here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gave him electric shock?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Yeah, we zapped him a few times. It's fairly standard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It says here thirty-eight... thirty- eight times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What will happen to him now, without the drugs he was on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MONK'S SECRETARY enters the office and hands him a folder. Without interrupting the delivery of his lines, Monk takes the folder, opens it, initials something on the inside, closes the folder and hands it back to the secretary who turns and leaves the office without uttering a word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Clifford looks at the doctor as if questioning his casual assessment of "some deterioration."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford directs a bleak look back down at the open folder, then looks up again, his eyes narrowing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They glare at each other for several seconds. Monk is the first one to look away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monk rises and walks to a window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monk looks back out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK There'll be some deterioration. That's inevitable, but we can't say how much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: During the time that you had him here, did you discover any particular habits of his, peculiarities, quirks, anything that might help me find him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK (shrugging again) It's all in the folder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any letters from people back in England? Family?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK That, too, is in the folder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's get something straight here, Doctor. I've been 33 years in the business of tracking people down and putting them away. I spent almost a year on Curt Duncan alone, with the trial, the testimonies, the background investigations. I didn't come here today to look in your goddamn folders. In fact, I wouldn't have come here at all if you'd done your job right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Mr. Clifford, this is a hospital, not a penitentiary. Everything that pertains to one of our patients is meticulously recorded in that patient's folder... whether you can make sense of it or not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Curt Duncan is a classic paranoid- schizophrenic. They see themselves as victims, and they always blame other people for the way they are. When Duncan killed the Mandrakis kids, it wasn't an act of hostility against the children but against their parents. He was getting back at his own parents for traumas he suffered in early childhood. The criminal side of Curt Duncan is one of terrible, symbolic vengeance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) Assuming he isn't found right away... what will happen to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK I think you'll find him. Somebody will find him. He can't function out there. He'll make a mistake. (turning to face Clifford) This is where he belongs. After six years in here, he's suddenly gone out to confront the world again. I think he's in for a bit of a shock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Not a terribly good section of town. We are looking at the nondescript exterior of a bar across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not a slum bar, but it's close. There are a few tables and chairs and a pool table in the back. The atmosphere is quiet, almost depressed, and the handful of REGULARS here are exercising their privacy without having to be alone. They include: HANK, the bartender, also the owner, who absently polishes things with his cloth; TRACY, an unemployed woman in her mid-forties who sits at the bar with a drink and a cigarette and silently rummages through her current feelings -- none of them new or particularly hopeful; a COUPLE, probably retired, sitting at the same table they come to every afternoon at this time -- him for his beer, her for a glass of sweet white wine; and BILL, at the pool table, a young man lithe and powerful, minding his own business and playing his game of pool with a steady, aggressive concentration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man smiles stupidly around the room. He racked 'em up a little in his day, too. His smile fades as he looks at his wife. He takes a sip of beer and lapses into memories. Then the door opens to the outside and the yellow-orange light of late afternoon floods into the bar. The regulars turn to glimpse who's coming in. They see the figure of a MAN silhouetted in the doorway. He stands there for a long moment, not coming in. Finally even Bill interrupts his game to turn and look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The intruder enters, indecisively. The door swings shut behind him, plunging the room back into darkness. This man is "a little weird", and the regulars continue to stare at him until he makes his way to a table near the wall and sits down. Then everyone returns to his own thoughts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rackin' 'em up today, Bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over his shoulder) Doin' all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon in and shut the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) What'll it be? (pause, no answer) Hey! What'll it be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A bit startled, a bit defensive toward the directness of this question. It is Curt Duncan. He looks understandably harried. He hasn't slept or shaved in at least a couple of days, and is wearing regular clothing. He clears his throat to answer...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) What kind of clothes was he wearing... when he escaped?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MONK'S OFFICE -DAY Clifford is looking through the folder again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking down, Clifford pauses over a page in the folder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Ordinary street clothes. Not all of our patients have to wear the green Gucci gowns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did he have any money with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Probably. But not more than, say, fifty dollars. Some of the patients are given little jobs around the ward, for which they are paid. It's part of the rehabilitation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A page of legibly organized facts and statistics about Curt Duncan. One of the entries reads: Guy du Marraux.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (reading) What's Guy du Mar--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK (O.S.) (pronouncing it correctly) Guy du Marraux syndrom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MONK It's a psycho-motor dysfunction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens a file cabinet drawer, finds a reel of quarter-inch magnetic tape and starts to thread it through a recorder on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a pause as Monk fiddles with the tape recorder and Clifford looks back down at the folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford smiles. Monk keeps fiddling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monk turns on the tape recorder as Clifford sits forward in his chair to listen. At first, nothing can be heard. Then there is a click as if the machine was turned on in the middle of a conversation:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford nods and keeps listening:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are scuffling noises underneath which can be heard, heavy breathing and then, getting louder and more furious, Duncan falling into the throes of Guy du Marraux.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally Monk is heard no more and Duncan continues with the frightening verbal torrent of Guy du Marraux.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Duncan had it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Only from time to time, which is unusual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK It attacks the nervous system. People suffering from it are irresistibly compelled to utter obscenities, sometimes one, sometimes a whole string of them. They can't control it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (somewhat taken aback) Are you being serious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Yeah. Here, I'll give you an example.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Duncan never had the twitch that sometimes goes with it. And with Duncan, as I said, the disease would only manifest itself in periods of extreme anxiety. When he was really flipping out, in other words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Duncan was Catholic?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Yeah. (beat) So am I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly surprised) That makes three of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Is that right? So we all share the same guilt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK Here. This is Curt Duncan shortly after he was admitted here in 1972.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK (O.S.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: to put the situation right. The hypodermic needles are only used to give you medication that will calm you down. They make you feel good, relaxed. All right? (no answer) We're not putting anything in your food either. The food is just food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (extremely agitated) No. I don't eat the food. It doesn't taste right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK (to Clifford) That's Duncan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK (O.S.) Curt, why are you fidgeting? Can't you get comfortable?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No, I'm not comfortable!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK (O.S.) Wait a -- Hey! (to someone else) Hold him down there. Grab him! Never mind the chair!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MONK (O.S.) (periodically interjecting) Pull him down... That's right... Just lay him out... Lay him right out... Steady... Pull out his knees...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE AFTERNOON - CLOSEUP - DUNCAN Sitting at his table inside the bar. He takes a long, noisy drink from what looks like a bourbon on the rocks. It tastes good, being the first real drink he's had in over six years. But Duncan cannot relax enough to enjoy it fully. His eyes are ever restlessly, suspiciously moving about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Bill walks up and stands next to Tracy. Hank moves off to get Bill another beer. Tracy looks up at Bill and smiles. As regulars at the same bar, they are loose and comfortable with each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both turn and look across the room at Duncan.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto voce) A little action for your game?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto voce) What, him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Bill and Tracy look straight at him over their shoulders and then turn back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they both smile at her joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracy grimaces as Hank comes back with Bill's beer. Bill picks up the bottle, nods his thanks to Hank and heads back to the pool table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't bet against you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter? You don't like me playing with myself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As his eyes follow Bill to the pool table, then come back to Tracy at the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking at the back of Tracy. She reaches into her purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes her pack of cigarettes from the purse. She pulls out a cigarette, taps it lightly on the bar, puts it to her lips. O.S. we hear the sound of a match being struck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Duncan is standing beside her holding a lit match. He shoves it forward at her. It goes out. Duncan fumbles for another match as Tracy regards him with undisguised repulsion. Duncan gets the second match lit and holds it out for her. She accepts the favor and lights her cigarette. Duncan smiles. Tracy nods and turns away. Duncan is still holding the burning match for her to blow out. As it doesn't look like she's going to, he lets it drop, still lit, to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives a look as if to say, "Jesus, what a fuckin' weirdo".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Duncan is still smiling at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Englishman sits down beside her, but doesn't look at her. Tracy looks away too, determined to ignore him, not to let him get into her space. Duncan coughs. After a long moment, he turns back to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracy keeps her eyes straight ahead, acknowledging nothing. Pause. Duncan takes some money from his pocket and lays it on the bar, staring at her. Tracy turns to him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks away again. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longer pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracy abruptly picks up her purse and moves down the bar away from him one seat, then another seat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you been up to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at him) My own business. (beat) Thanks for the light. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next round's on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) Listen, mister, I've got my own money. So, if you don't mind...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After what I been through, I don't mind anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See, that's the whole point. My mind... Your mind... Where do they fit in? You know what I mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They are watching this little spectacle with growing curiosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still looking at her. By pointing at what she has, he orders two more drinks from the Bartender. When they arrive, he takes a big swallow from one, picks up the other, stands, moves down the bar and sits beside Tracy again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (setting her drink before her) Do you live around here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get offa me!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S Even Bill now looks up from the pool table. His expression darkens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracy has clammed up -- her elbows on the bar, head between her elbows, arms covering her ears, hands clasped behind her neck. Duncan looks at her nervously and starts to talk again:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan looks up. Bill enters the frame and stands in front of Tracy, confronting Duncan.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (rapidly) Listen, I didn't mean nothin'. I don't live around here. See -- ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) I think the lady wants to be left alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Looking up at Bill, his eyes red, his gaze unsteady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE The air is charged with tension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan doesn't know how to handle this. He looks at Bill, half shrugs, half smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan looks away. A long moment passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan doesn't move, says nothing. He swallows hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bartender steps back, deciding to mind his own business. Tracy gets up from her seat and cautiously moves even further down the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They glare at each other. The longer Duncan sits there without moving, without saying anything, the angrier Bill gets.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think an apology is in order.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That the best you can do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you'd better just move along, pal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll be okay now, Bill. He just -- BILL No! I want him out of here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Duncan) Go on, beat it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S As the tension builds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan reaches for his drink, but Bill reacts quicker. With a swipe of his hand, he knocks the glass off the bar, and it shatters on the floor behind the bar. Duncan sits there, stunned, not looking up. After a long moment, Duncan coughs. Then he turns and looks at Bill. He purses his lips. It looks like a nervous facial movement. Then suddenly, Duncan spits at Bill, hitting him square in the face. Before anyone can register what's happened, Bill lunges at Duncan, knocking him clean off the barstool and onto the floor. The fight is fast, vicious and one-sided from the very start. Pinned to the floor on his back, Duncan flails his arms ineffectually like a panicked insect as Bill holds him in place with a left-handed grip on the collar while his powerful right arm, pumping up and down like a piston, pounds into Duncan's face time and time again. Duncan's screams diminish into pathetic, sickening groans and the others in the bar are compelled to avert their eyes from this brutal spectacle. Hank has picked up a phone from beneath the bar and is dialing a number. He turns away from the fight to talk. Then, as suddenly as Bill first sprang at Duncan, he leaps to his feet and turns to the bar. He reaches over and grabs the phone from Hank, slamming it down into the cradle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill takes the cloth from the bar and vigorously wipes his face off. He snaps his fingers and points to a row of bottles on a shelf behind the bar. Hank quickly hands him a bottle. Bill pours himself a shot and downs it, fast. He is still charged with adrenaline and he takes two more shots in rapid succession, spilling the alcohol on the bar and on himself. As Bill picks up the cloth to wipe himself off again, Tracy stands up and quickly walks out of the bar, slamming the door behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he throws down the cloth, picks up the bottle, turns and, standing over Duncan's inert form, empties half the bottle onto him. He sets the bottle back on the bar. He grabs Duncan and, half dragging, hurries him out the back door and throws him into the alley where Duncan falls in a heap. Bill storms back up to the bar and pours himself another drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hank just looks at him, doesn't answer. At the wife's silent insistence, the elderly couple stand up to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill doesn't answer and the couple quietly leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hank lowers his gaze to the floor. Bill finishes his drink. He is still very hopped up. He pulls a few dollars from his wallet and drops them on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and strides out of the bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to say it again, mister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who're you calling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling after her) You're welcome, baby!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hank) Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good riddance to bad rubbish, eh, Bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (apologetic) A fight breaks out, there's gonna be damages. Insurance company doesn't pay without a police report...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see any damages?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See ya 'round.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: for a beat on Hank alone now in his empty establishment. The phone starts to ring, presumably the police calling back. After several rings, Hank picks up the phone and listens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) No, it's over now...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GARBER'S HOUSE - NIGHT All the lights are out inside the house, but we should just be able to see that we are in the hall, looking at the front door. Footsteps approach on the walk outside. A key slips into the lock... Inside the house we can hear faint whispering. Someone is moving about in the darkness. Then the door swings open and the shadowy figure of a MAN crosses the threshold. He stops just inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly the lights come on and a chorus of voices cry out, "SURPRISE!" A broad smile breaks across the man's face. We may recognize him as the cop from six years ago -- Charles Garber. Today he is a lieutenant on the force and dresses casually for work, usually in slacks, turtleneck and jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Garber looks sheepishly at his hand holding the pistol he'd drawn just before the lights came up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody starts to laugh, including Garber as he returns the pistol to his shoulder holster.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling out) Donna. Donna! Hey! (under his breath) What the hell -- !
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (genuinely surprised) What is all this?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happy birthday, Charlie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't shoot us, Charlie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chagrined) How was I supposed to know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Garber's wife. She comes out of the kitchen carrying a birthday cake with lit candles and makes her way through the crowd of GUESTS singing "Happy Birthday". Everyone joins in as Donna moves forward and stands beside her husband. Clifford is one of the guests. He has his arm around a young BLOND who is sort of pretty despite her tacky/plastic appearance. When the song is over, Garber blows out the candles and hugs and kisses his wife. Everybody cheers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The party is still in full swing. Garber is following Clifford up the stairs. They are both fairly loaded by now. Garber, in particular, has reached that stage of inebriation where standing still is pretty hard to do.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Will you tell me what this is about, Cliff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, in a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I can take any more of these surprises.

direction.raw_text: It is late. The block is virtually deserted. Across the street is the exterior of a bar -- the same bar Duncan was in earlier. Some PEOPLE are coming out of the bar. It must be near closing time. The people turn left and walk away down the sidewalk. Their voices diminish. Pause. A car passes. Then the door to the bar opens again and a woman comes out onto the sidewalk. It is Tracy. She turns to the right and starts to walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is standing in shadows across the street, watching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A series of shots of Tracy walking home. The CAMERA remains consistently behind her or off to one side, sometimes DOLLYING with her behind a row of parked cars, sometimes picking up her passing reflection in a darkened store window. The impression this gives is unmistakable. Curt Duncan is following her. We do not see him, we do not hear him, yet we know he is there. Often we can sense that the very angle from which we see Tracy is his POV. But Tracy is aware of nothing. We know this when the CAMERA begins to move in front of her, once more becoming an impersonal observer of her walk homeward, to safety. Tension mounts as we start to expect that Duncan will jump out at her from every alley and recessed doorway she passes. But he doesn't. Finally, Tracy walks up to the CAMERA at the end of a block and turns a corner; but the CAMERA HOLDS on the dark street she has just come up. We hear a cough which confirms that Duncan is lurking somewhere in the shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracy walks up the steps and enters the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracy steps into the elevator. The doors close. CAMERA HOLDS on the elevator and watches the lights above it travel from one to six. O.S. we hear the door to the apartment building open and close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracy steps out of the elevator and walks down the hall to her door. She fumbles through her purse for keys, then bends over the lock to let herself in. Behind her down the hall, Duncan appears. He watches her, starts to move silently forward. Tracy gets the door open, then turns and sees him. Duncan stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan half shrugs, half smiles. Tracy edges into her door- way. Duncan stands opposite her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other. Duncan coughs again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside Tracy's apartment, the telephone rings. Tracy turns vaguely, indecisively, and goes to answer it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She disappears into the apartment. O.S. she picks up the ringing phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it's you! (beat) What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (moving forward) ...Came to apologize. I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I'm the one who should be sorry. I didn't want that to happen. (she sees his face; shudders) Oh, God! Look at you. Are you all right.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm new in town. Don't know anybody...

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortable) Where're you from?

dialogue.raw_text: (coughs) New York. Ever been there?

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Sure I've been there.

dialogue.raw_text: Kind of a mean place to be. Everyone cold, unfriendly...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over her shoulder) Excuse me.

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello?...

direction.raw_text: As she sits with the telephone.

direction.raw_text: He sits down.

direction.raw_text: Duncan looks at her for a moment, then looks about the apartment.

Outside the door, Duncan's footsteps move down the hall, pause, then come back to the door. A moment passes. Then there is a faint knocking on the door. Tracy doesn't move. The knocking comes again, a little louder this time. Tracy stands and waits, scarcely breathing. After another long moment, the footsteps finally move away.

dialogue.raw_text: (nervous) ...No, I just got in... I don't know if I can... Listen, I can't talk now. Can I call you back?... Okay... Goodbye.

Clifford underlines the fourth -- BACK TO SCENE Clifford looks up from the pad to a bar he has pulled up in front of -- the bar Duncan was in. It bears the address Clifford has just underlined. Clifford gets out of his car and walks up to the bar. A "Closed" sign is displayed in the window. Clifford knocks on the door. After a moment, Hank opens the door.

dialogue.raw_text: He's escaped from the insane asylum. In 1972, he murdered two children... broke into a house and found them asleep in bed. It was a little boy, five an a half, and a little three- year-old girl. After the coroner's investigation, their bodies were taken to the mortuary, where the undertaker took one look at them and said he couldn't have their bodies reconstructed for the funeral without six days of steady work. Then he asked what had been the murder weapon, because looking at the mess in front of him, he couldn't imagine what had been used. The coroner told him there had been no murder weapon. The killer had used only his hands. (beat) The undertaker went to work and had them done in four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

The waitress looks at the man irritatedly, then picks up the money and moves away. Duncan slowly sits down again. He pulls the cup back to himself, then turns and looks at the man for a long moment, unable to express his gratitude.

direction.raw_text: A series of shots of BUMS, "homeless persons", hanging out, in alleys, in the doorways of old buildings, sitting on the sidewalk in front of liquor stores. Then we see Duncan, alone but looking no different from the others. He is panhandling PASSERSBY, without much success. We see him fall into a fit of coughing that incapacitates him for several seconds. He's obviously getting sicker. We lose sight of Duncan as our MONTAGE continues. We see Clifford talking to a BUM, then another. He is passing the time combing the streets in the neighborhood of the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A handful of BUMS are sitting together on the grass passing a bottle in a brown paper bag. Duncan is not among them, but Cheater is there, sitting at the end of the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S from one bum to the next as the bottle is passed. By the time it gets to Cheater, it is empty. Cheater looks as if he's about to cry like a baby when a hand enters the frame from the other side -- the hand holding out to Cheater a full bottle of wine. Cheater takes the bottle and looks up gratefully... to see John Clifford standing beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheater takes a long drink, then passes the bottle back down the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody responds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheater scratches his head, and glances anxiously down the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford stands to go. The bottle comes back to Cheater, three-quarters down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clifford is gone. Cheater takes a long drink and almost forgets that Clifford was ever there.

dialogue.raw_text: Well! I can't say much for your protocol, but your timing's dead on. Here's to you, pardner.

dialogue.raw_text: (to all the bums) I'm looking for an old buddy of mine, English fella. Name's Crazy Curt. Any of you guys seen him?

dialogue.raw_text: Aaahh. Show me an honest man...

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah? I was just with that guy, not more'n an hour ago. Looked bad. Crazy Curt, huh?
